newsitem.title: JAPAN: Asia's crude refining shortage seen growing--study.
newsitem.headline: Asia's crude refining shortage seen growing--study.

text.p: A shortage in Asia's crude refining capacity is expected to worsen as demand for oil products in the region outpaces construction of new refining units, a study by an oil industry body said on Wednesday.

The study by the Petroleum Association of Japan (PAJ) forecasts the deficit in refining capacity in Asian countries, excluding Japan, to grow from 523,000 barrels per day (bpd) in 1995 to 881,000 bpd in 2000 and 1.24 million bpd in 2005.
Japan is not included in the study, which aims to find out what impact Asia's oil product output and demand will have on Japan's import market.
On April 1, Japan liberalised its oil product import market, which was previously dominated by refiners.
The 14 countries covered in the survey were China, South Korea, Taiwan, the Philippines, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, Vietnam, Singapore, Pakistan, India, Sri Lanka and Australia.
Demand for oil products in the 14 countries is expected to increase by 45.7 percent from 1995 to 15.6 million barrels per day (bpd) in 2005, the study showed.
Growth in crude processing capacity is forecast to lag behind, rising by 40.2 percent to 16.14 million bpd, it said.
The PAJ said the shortfall in oil product supplies would be be sufficiently covered through imports and production from newly constructed refineries in Asia.
When looking at Asian refining capacity, the report noted two recent developments.

Having experienced the Gulf crisis in the early 1990s when Iraq invaded Kuwait, an increasing number of Asian countries are planning to construct their own crude refineries in order to secure stable supplies.
Also, non-oil companies are planning to enter the refining business. Taiwan's Formosa Plastics Corp and Thai Petrochemical Industry Plc both have plans to build large refining units, the PAJ said.
Formosa is expected to export oil products other than naphtha, which it will consume itself, to China, it said.
Increased production of natural gas in the Middle East, in countries such as Qatar, Abu Dhabi and Oman, is also expected to help relieve Asia's growing appetite for middle distillates.
Condensates share many of the characteristics of exceptionally light crudes.
Light crudes tend to yield a greater amount of middle distillates, such as gas oil and kerosene.
